title: Python Data Types: str, int, float, and bool
description: Learn to evaluate expressions and identify the data types Python assigns to variables

blocks.title: Introduction to Python Data Types
blocks.content:
# Python Data Types

Every value in Python has a type. Understanding data types is crucial because it determines what operations you can perform with your data. Python has four fundamental data types that we'll explore:

1. **str (String)** - Text data enclosed in quotes
2. **int (Integer)** - Whole numbers without decimal points
3. **float (Floating-point)** - Numbers with decimal points
4. **bool (Boolean)** - True or False values

Let's dive into each type and learn how to identify them!

blocks.title: String Examples
blocks.code:
# String examples
name = "Alice"              # Text in double quotes
message = 'Hello, World!'   # Text in single quotes
age_text = "16"            # Numbers in quotes are strings!
multiline = '''This is
a multiline
string'''                   # Triple quotes for multiple lines

# Checking the type
print(type(name))          # <class 'str'>
print(type(age_text))      # <class 'str'> - not a number!
blocks.explanation: Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes. You can use single (''), double (""), or triple (''' or """) quotes. Remember: anything inside quotes becomes a string, even numbers!

blocks.title: Integer Examples
blocks.code:
# Integer examples
age = 16                   # Positive whole number
score = -5                 # Negative whole number
count = 0                  # Zero is also an integer
big_number = 1_000_000     # Underscores for readability

# Checking the type
print(type(age))           # <class 'int'>
print(type(score))         # <class 'int'>

# Common mistake
wrong = "16"               # This is a string, not an integer!
print(type(wrong))         # <class 'str'>
blocks.explanation: Integers are whole numbers without decimal points. They can be positive, negative, or zero. Python allows underscores in large numbers for better readability.

blocks.title: Float Examples
blocks.code:
# Float examples
height = 5.7               # Decimal number
temperature = -10.5        # Negative decimal
pi = 3.14159              # Many decimal places
scientific = 1.5e-4       # Scientific notation (0.00015)

# Checking the type
print(type(height))        # <class 'float'>
print(type(pi))           # <class 'float'>

# Important: Division always returns a float
result = 10 / 2           # Even though 10รท2=5
print(result)             # 5.0
print(type(result))       # <class 'float'>
blocks.explanation: Floats represent decimal numbers. They're called 'floating-point' because the decimal point can 'float' to different positions. Division in Python always returns a float, even when dividing evenly.

blocks.title: Boolean Examples
blocks.code:
# Boolean examples
is_student = True          # Note the capital T
has_homework = False       # Note the capital F

# Booleans from comparisons
age = 16
can_drive = age >= 16      # True
is_adult = age >= 18       # False

# Checking the type
print(type(is_student))    # <class 'bool'>
print(type(can_drive))     # <class 'bool'>

# Common mistake
wrong_bool = "True"       # This is a string!
print(type(wrong_bool))    # <class 'str'>
blocks.explanation: Booleans represent truth values: True or False. They're often the result of comparisons or logical operations. Remember: True and False must be capitalized in Python!

blocks.title: Identify the Data Type
blocks.instructions: Write a function that takes a value and returns a string describing its type in plain English.
blocks.starter_code:
def identify_type(value):
    # Your code here
    # Return "integer", "string", "float", or "boolean"
    pass

# Test your function
print(identify_type(42))        # Should return "integer"
print(identify_type("42"))      # Should return "string"
print(identify_type(42.0))      # Should return "float"
print(identify_type(True))      # Should return "boolean"

blocks.title: Data Types Knowledge Check
blocks.description: Test your understanding of Python data types

questions.question: What is the data type of x = '123'?
questions.explanation: Even though it contains numbers, anything in quotes is a string.

questions.question: Which of these will result in a float type?
questions.explanation: Division (/) always returns a float in Python, even when dividing evenly.

questions.question: The value False is of type bool.
questions.explanation: False (with capital F) is one of Python's two boolean values.

questions.question: What type is the result of: type(42).__name__?
questions.explanation: The __name__ attribute gives the type name as a string without the class notation.

questions.question: A variable in Python can change its data type during program execution.
questions.explanation: Python is dynamically typed, allowing variables to hold different types of values.
